individual_answers: The optimal bidding strategy is to **bid your true valuation of $100**.

The optimal bidding strategy in a second-price sealed-bid auction (Vickrey auction) is to bid your true valuation of the item. If your valuation is $100, you should bid $100. This strategy ensures that you win the item if and only if the second-highest bid is less than or equal to your valuation. If you win, you pay the second-highest bid, which is the lowest price that allows you to win, thus maximizing your profit (valuation minus price paid). Bidding more than your valuation risks paying more than the item is worth to you, while bidding less risks losing the item when you could have won it profitably.
The backward induction predicts that the first player will take immediately at the first turn, ending the game with $1, and the second player will receive nothing.

Backward induction predicts that **all players will pass on every turn, the game will continue until all 6 passes are made, and Player 2 (the second player) will receive the entire pot of $64**. This occurs because at each stage, looking forward, each player can see they will receive more by passing (allowing the pot to grow) than by taking the current pot value.

answers.majority_answer: The backward induction predicts that the first player will take immediately at the first turn, ending the game with $1, and the second player will receive nothing.

individual_answers: Both companies advertising is the Nash equilibrium.

The Nash equilibrium is for both companies to advertise, with each earning $3M. This is a dominant strategy equilibrium where advertising is the best response for each company regardless of what the other company does. Although both companies would be better off if neither advertised ($5M each), the individual incentive to advertise (earning $6M if the other doesn't) makes mutual advertising the equilibrium outcome.
The Nash equilibrium is when both companies advertise.
answers.majority_answer: Both companies advertising is the Nash equilibrium.
